001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on int coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * an int for state; the code is similar to {@link HastyPointHash} but will be much faster on GWT. This
006 * implementation has high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would
007 * likely not be a good option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of
008 * {@link Coord#hashCode()}; it is still better than {@link java.util.Objects#hash(Object...)}). Even on a desktop
009 * JVM, this class is faster than {@link PointHash} or {@link HastyPointHash}. The technique used here
010 * owes credit to Pelle Evensen for finding the significant quality increase from using multiple bitwise rotations XORed
011 * together, and Martin Roberts for discovering the connection between higher dimensional ranks and the appropriate
012 * numbers to gain similar qualities to adding the golden ratio mod 1 in 1D, using what had already been named
013 * "harmonious numbers." The only case where this can return different results on GWT than on a desktop or mobile
014 * JVM is when the inputs are GWT-specific out-of-range JS Numbers appearing to be ints, and that's a problem with
015 * the input rather than the algorithm.
016 * <br>
017 * Getting the bottom 24 bits of {@link #hashAll(int, int, int)}, dividing to get a float from 0 to 1, and graphing
018 * it produces <a href="https://i.imgur.com/vYWzVAR.png">this white-noise-like image</a>. The frequency magnitude of
019 * that image is <a href="https://i.imgur.com/6N39FPQ.png">this diagram</a>, which looks almost exactly like
020 * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/RSdUnSY.png">a diagram of the frequency magnitude of white noise</a>. This shows
021 * there are effectively no significant structural artifacts in the noise when interpreted as a float.
022 */
023public class IntPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
024
025    public static final IntPointHash INSTANCE = new IntPointHash();
026
027    public IntPointHash() {
028        super();
029    }
030
031    public IntPointHash(int state) {
032        super(state);
033    }
034
035    @Override
036    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
037        return hashAll(x, y, state);
038    }
039
040    @Override
041    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
042        return hashAll(x, y, z, state);
043    }
044
045    @Override
046    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
047        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
048    }
049
050    @Override
051    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
052        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
053    }
054
055    @Override
056    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
057        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
058    }
059
060    /**
061     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
062     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
063     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
064     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
065     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
066     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
067     * @param x x position, as an int
068     * @param y y position, as an int
069     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
070     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
071     */
072    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int s) {
073        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
074        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
075    }
076    /**
077     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
078     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
079     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
080     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
081     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
082     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
083     * @param x x position, as an int
084     * @param y y position, as an int
085     * @param z z position, as an int
086     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
087     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
088     */
089    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
090        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
091        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
092    }
093
094    /**
095     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
096     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
097     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
098     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
099     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
100     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
101     * @param x x position, as an int
102     * @param y y position, as an int
103     * @param z z position, as an int
104     * @param w w position, as an int
105     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
106     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
107     */
108    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
109        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
110        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
111    }
112
113    /**
114     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
115     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
116     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
117     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
118     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
119     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
120     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
121     * @param x x position, as an int
122     * @param y y position, as an int
123     * @param z z position, as an int
124     * @param w w position, as an int
125     * @param u u position, as an int
126     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
127     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state s
128     */
129    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int s) {
130        s ^= x * 0x1C3360 ^ y * 0x18DA3A ^ z * 0x15E6DA ^ w * 0x134D28 ^ u * 0x110280;
131        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
132    }
133
134    /**
135     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
136     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
137     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
138     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
139     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
140     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
141     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
142     * @param x x position, as an int
143     * @param y y position, as an int
144     * @param z z position, as an int
145     * @param w w position, as an int
146     * @param u u position, as an int
147     * @param v v position, as an int
148     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
149     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
150     */
151    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
152        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
153        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
154    }
155
156    /**
157     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
158     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
159     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
160     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
161     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
162     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
163     * @param x x position, as an int
164     * @param y y position, as an int
165     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
166     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
167     */
168    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int s) {
169        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
170        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
171    }
172    /**
173     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
174     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
175     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
176     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
177     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
178     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
179     * @param x x position, as an int
180     * @param y y position, as an int
181     * @param z z position, as an int
182     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
183     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
184     */
185    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
186        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
187        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
188    }

190    /**
191     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
192     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
193     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
194     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
195     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
196     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
197     * @param x x position, as an int
198     * @param y y position, as an int
199     * @param z z position, as an int
200     * @param w w position, as an int
201     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
202     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
203     */
204    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
205        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
206        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
207    }

209    /**
210     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
211     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
212     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
213     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
214     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
215     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
216     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
217     * @param x x position, as an int
218     * @param y y position, as an int
219     * @param z z position, as an int
220     * @param w w position, as an int
221     * @param u u position, as an int
222     * @param v v position, as an int
223     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
224     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
225     */
226    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
227        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
228        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
229    }

231    /**
232     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
233     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
234     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
235     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
236     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
237     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
238     * @param x x position, as an int
239     * @param y y position, as an int
240     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
241     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
242     */
243    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int s) {
244        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
245        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
246    }
247    /**
248     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
249     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
250     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
251     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
252     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
253     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
254     * @param x x position, as an int
255     * @param y y position, as an int
256     * @param z z position, as an int
257     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
258     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
259     */
260    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
261        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
262        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
263    }

265    /**
266     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
267     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
268     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
269     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
270     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
271     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
272     * @param x x position, as an int
273     * @param y y position, as an int
274     * @param z z position, as an int
275     * @param w w position, as an int
276     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
277     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
278     */
279    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
280        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
281        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
282    }

284    /**
285     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
286     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
287     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
288     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
289     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
290     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
291     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
292     * @param x x position, as an int
293     * @param y y position, as an int
294     * @param z z position, as an int
295     * @param w w position, as an int
296     * @param u u position, as an int
297     * @param v v position, as an int
298     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
299     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
300     */
301    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
302        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
303        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
304    }
305    /**
306     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
307     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
308     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
309     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
310     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
311     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
312     * @param x x position, as an int
313     * @param y y position, as an int
314     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
315     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
316     */
317    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int s) {
318        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
319        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
320    }

339    /**
340     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
341     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
342     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
343     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
344     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
345     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
346     * @param x x position, as an int
347     * @param y y position, as an int
348     * @param z z position, as an int
349     * @param w w position, as an int
350     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
351     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
352     */
353    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
354        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
355        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
356    }

358    /**
359     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
360     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
361     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
362     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
363     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
364     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
365     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
366     * @param x x position, as an int
367     * @param y y position, as an int
368     * @param z z position, as an int
369     * @param w w position, as an int
370     * @param u u position, as an int
371     * @param v v position, as an int
372     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
373     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
374     */
375    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
376        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
377        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
378    }
